title: 112_hr2093
content: The "Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Investigative Commission Act" establishes a commission to investigate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Commission is tasked with conducting an investigation into these entities. The Commission will investigate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's policies, practices, and board decisions that led to financial instability and federal conservatorship. It will analyze their roles in expanding homeownership, aiding the housing market recovery, and their involvement in developing faulty risk standards and accounting. The investigation will focus on the development of faulty risk standards, accounting practices, and securitized mortgage instruments that affected the solvency of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. It will also examine the role of the boards of directors in setting investment, accounting, and contracting policies related to risk assessments, subprime mortgages, and international securitization. Additionally, it will look into the decisions made by board members, working committees, and executive officers regarding risk assessments and the growth of subprime mortgage portfolios. The investigation will focus on the decisions of the boards and executive officers of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac that may have led to the overvaluation of risky mortgage investments and the growth of the subprime mortgage industry. It will also examine the annual compensation of executive officers and board members, as well as any other matters that Congress may bring before the Commission. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed by various leaders in the House of Representatives and Senate. Members must have expertise in banking, securities, consumer advocacy, fair housing programs, and the mortgage industry. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives and Senate. Members must not have conflicts of interest and will be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Chairperson is designated by the Speaker of the House, and each member serves for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's power and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. Federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional compensation. The Commission must meet at least quarterly. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members, in addition to quarterly meetings. A quorum consists of five members, but hearings can be held with a lesser number. Members can meet using telephones or other suitable technologies as long as all members can communicate simultaneously. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson with experience in banking, securities, finance regulation, consumer advocacy, fair housing, and the mortgage industry. The Director's salary is determined by the Chairperson and cannot exceed the rate of basic pay for GS-15. The Director can appoint additional staff with approval and procure temporary services with approval of the Commission. The Director can procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-15. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence, and enforce compliance through court orders. The United States district court can order a person to appear before the Commission for testimony or evidence related to an investigation. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt. Members and agents of the Commission can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies to fulfill its duties under the Act. The Architect of the Capitol will provide facilities and equipment for the Commission, while administrative support services will be offered by the Administrator of the General Services. The Commission has the authority to establish bylaws, rules, and regulations, and must maintain accurate records of its activities. The Commission must maintain complete records of its activities for public inspection and audit by the Comptroller General or his designee. SEC. 8. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as the FHFA, must provide necessary information to the Commission. SEC. 9 mandates a final report to Congress within 12 months of all initial members being appointed. SEC. 10 authorizes appropriations for the Commission in fiscal year 2011. SEC. 11 outlines the termination of the Commission. SEC. 11. The Commission will end after submitting its final report and recommendations under section 9, within 30 days of submission.
